SR Text: Each sequence number is set to zero at the beginning of a connection and whenever the key is changed; the first record transmitted under a particular traffic key MUST use sequence number 0.
Conditions: At the beginning of a connection,Whenever the key is changed
Actions: The first record transmitted under a particular traffic key MUST use sequence number 0 (i.e., the sequence number is set to zero)
Current Paragraph: A 64-bit sequence number is maintained separately for reading and writing records. The appropriate sequence number is incremented by one after reading or writing each record. Each sequence number is set to zero at the beginning of a connection and whenever the key is changed; the first record transmitted under a particular traffic key MUST use sequence number 0.
Next Paragraph: Because the size of sequence numbers is 64-bit, they should not wrap. If a TLS implementation would need to wrap a sequence number, it MUST either rekey (Section 4.6.3) or terminate the connection.

SR Text: If a TLS implementation would need to wrap a sequence number, it MUST either rekey (Section 4.6.3) or terminate the connection.
Conditions: When a TLS implementation is about to wrap a sequence number (i.e., when the sequence number reaches its maximum value and would roll over)
Actions: The TLS implementation MUST either rekey (as specified in Section 4.6.3) or terminate the connection
Current Paragraph: Because the size of sequence numbers is 64-bit, they should not wrap. If a TLS implementation would need to wrap a sequence number, it MUST either rekey (Section 4.6.3) or terminate the connection.
Previous Paragraph: A 64-bit sequence number is maintained separately for reading and writing records. The appropriate sequence number is incremented by one after reading or writing each record. Each sequence number is set to zero at the beginning of a connection and whenever the key is changed; the first record transmitted under a particular traffic key MUST use sequence number 0.
Next Paragraph: Each AEAD algorithm will specify a range of possible lengths for the per-record nonce, from N_MIN bytes to N_MAX bytes of input [RFC5116]. The length of the TLS per-record nonce (iv_length) is set to the larger of 8 bytes and N_MIN for the AEAD algorithm (see [RFC5116], Section 4). An AEAD algorithm where N_MAX is less than 8 bytes MUST NOT be used with TLS. The per-record nonce for the AEAD construction is formed as follows: 1. The 64-bit record sequence number is encoded in network byte order and padded to the left with zeros to iv_length. 2. The padded sequence number is XORed with either the static client_write_iv or server_write_iv (depending on the role).

SR Text: An AEAD algorithm where N_MAX is less than 8 bytes MUST NOT be used with TLS.
Conditions: An AEAD algorithm where N_MAX is less than 8 bytes
Actions: MUST NOT be used with TLS
Current Paragraph: Each AEAD algorithm will specify a range of possible lengths for the per-record nonce, from N_MIN bytes to N_MAX bytes of input [RFC5116]. The length of the TLS per-record nonce (iv_length) is set to the larger of 8 bytes and N_MIN for the AEAD algorithm (see [RFC5116], Section 4). An AEAD algorithm where N_MAX is less than 8 bytes MUST NOT be used with TLS. The per-record nonce for the AEAD construction is formed as follows: 1. The 64-bit record sequence number is encoded in network byte order and padded to the left with zeros to iv_length. 2. The padded sequence number is XORed with either the static client_write_iv or server_write_iv (depending on the role).
Previous Paragraph: Because the size of sequence numbers is 64-bit, they should not wrap. If a TLS implementation would need to wrap a sequence number, it MUST either rekey (Section 4.6.3) or terminate the connection.
Next Paragraph: The resulting quantity (of length iv_length) is used as the per-record nonce.

SR Text: When generating a TLSCiphertext record, implementations MAY choose to pad.
Conditions: When generating a TLSCiphertext record.
Actions: Implementations MAY choose to pad the TLSCiphertext record.
Current Paragraph: When generating a TLSCiphertext record, implementations MAY choose to pad. An unpadded record is just a record with a padding length of zero. Padding is a string of zero-valued bytes appended to the ContentType field before encryption. Implementations MUST set the padding octets to all zeros before encrypting.
Previous Paragraph: All encrypted TLS records can be padded to inflate the size of the TLSCiphertext. This allows the sender to hide the size of the traffic from an observer.
Next Paragraph: Application Data records may contain a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content if the sender desires. This permits generation of plausibly sized cover traffic in contexts where the presence or absence of activity may be sensitive. Implementations MUST NOT send Handshake and Alert records that have a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content; if such a message is received, the receiving implementation MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.

SR Text: Implementations MUST set the padding octets to all zeros before encrypting.
Conditions: Immediately prior to performing encryption, i.e., when generating a TLSCiphertext record where padding is applied.
Actions: Set all padding octets to zero before encryption.
Current Paragraph: When generating a TLSCiphertext record, implementations MAY choose to pad. An unpadded record is just a record with a padding length of zero. Padding is a string of zero-valued bytes appended to the ContentType field before encryption. Implementations MUST set the padding octets to all zeros before encrypting.
Previous Paragraph: All encrypted TLS records can be padded to inflate the size of the TLSCiphertext. This allows the sender to hide the size of the traffic from an observer.
Next Paragraph: Application Data records may contain a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content if the sender desires. This permits generation of plausibly sized cover traffic in contexts where the presence or absence of activity may be sensitive. Implementations MUST NOT send Handshake and Alert records that have a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content; if such a message is received, the receiving implementation MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.

SR Text: Implementations MUST NOT send Handshake and Alert records that have a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content; if such a message is received, the receiving implementation MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Conditions: If a Handshake or Alert record with a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content is received
Actions: Terminate the connection with an 'unexpected_message' alert
Current Paragraph: Application Data records may contain a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content if the sender desires. This permits generation of plausibly sized cover traffic in contexts where the presence or absence of activity may be sensitive. Implementations MUST NOT send Handshake and Alert records that have a zero-length TLSInnerPlaintext.content; if such a message is received, the receiving implementation MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Previous Paragraph: When generating a TLSCiphertext record, implementations MAY choose to pad. An unpadded record is just a record with a padding length of zero. Padding is a string of zero-valued bytes appended to the ContentType field before encryption. Implementations MUST set the padding octets to all zeros before encrypting.
Next Paragraph: The padding sent is automatically verified by the record protection mechanism; upon successful decryption of a TLSCiphertext.encrypted_record, the receiving implementation scans the field from the end toward the beginning until it finds a non-zero octet. This non-zero octet is the content type of the message. This padding scheme was selected because it allows padding of any encrypted TLS record by an arbitrary size (from zero up to TLS record size limits) without introducing new content types. The design also enforces all-zero padding octets, which allows for quick detection of padding errors.

SR Text: Implementations MUST limit their scanning to the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption.
Conditions: When scanning the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption, no nonzero octet is found
Actions: Implementations MUST limit their scanning exclusively to the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption,If no nonzero octet is found in that cleartext, the connection MUST be terminated with an 'unexpected_message' alert
Current Paragraph: Implementations MUST limit their scanning to the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption. If a receiving implementation does not find a non-zero octet in the cleartext, it MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Previous Paragraph: The padding sent is automatically verified by the record protection mechanism; upon successful decryption of a TLSCiphertext.encrypted_record, the receiving implementation scans the field from the end toward the beginning until it finds a non-zero octet. This non-zero octet is the content type of the message. This padding scheme was selected because it allows padding of any encrypted TLS record by an arbitrary size (from zero up to TLS record size limits) without introducing new content types. The design also enforces all-zero padding octets, which allows for quick detection of padding errors.
Next Paragraph: The presence of padding does not change the overall record size limitations: the full encoded TLSInnerPlaintext MUST NOT exceed 2^14 + 1 octets. If the maximum fragment length is reduced --as, for example, by the record_size_limit extension from [RFC8449] --then the reduced limit applies to the full plaintext, including the content type and padding.

SR Text: If a receiving implementation does not find a non-zero octet in the cleartext, it MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Conditions: A receiving implementation does not find a non-zero octet in the cleartext.
Actions: Terminate the connection with an 'unexpected_message' alert.
Current Paragraph: Implementations MUST limit their scanning to the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption. If a receiving implementation does not find a non-zero octet in the cleartext, it MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Previous Paragraph: The padding sent is automatically verified by the record protection mechanism; upon successful decryption of a TLSCiphertext.encrypted_record, the receiving implementation scans the field from the end toward the beginning until it finds a non-zero octet. This non-zero octet is the content type of the message. This padding scheme was selected because it allows padding of any encrypted TLS record by an arbitrary size (from zero up to TLS record size limits) without introducing new content types. The design also enforces all-zero padding octets, which allows for quick detection of padding errors.
Next Paragraph: The presence of padding does not change the overall record size limitations: the full encoded TLSInnerPlaintext MUST NOT exceed 2^14 + 1 octets. If the maximum fragment length is reduced --as, for example, by the record_size_limit extension from [RFC8449] --then the reduced limit applies to the full plaintext, including the content type and padding.

SR Text: The presence of padding does not change the overall record size limitations: the full encoded TLSInnerPlaintext MUST NOT exceed 2^14 + 1 octets.
Conditions: The record includes padding (i.e. when padding is present)
Actions: The full encoded TLSInnerPlaintext MUST NOT exceed 2^14 + 1 octets, regardless of the presence of padding
Current Paragraph: The presence of padding does not change the overall record size limitations: the full encoded TLSInnerPlaintext MUST NOT exceed 2^14 + 1 octets. If the maximum fragment length is reduced --as, for example, by the record_size_limit extension from [RFC8449] --then the reduced limit applies to the full plaintext, including the content type and padding.
Previous Paragraph: Implementations MUST limit their scanning to the cleartext returned from the AEAD decryption. If a receiving implementation does not find a non-zero octet in the cleartext, it MUST terminate the connection with an "unexpected_message" alert.
Next Paragraph: Selecting a padding policy that suggests when and how much to pad is a complex topic and is beyond the scope of this specification. If the application-layer protocol on top of TLS has its own padding, it may be preferable to pad Application Data TLS records within the application layer. Padding for encrypted Handshake or Alert records must still be handled at the TLS layer, though. Later documents may define padding selection algorithms or define a padding policy request mechanism through TLS extensions or some other means.

SR Text: Implementations SHOULD do a key update as described in Section 4.6.3 prior to reaching these limits.
Conditions: When the amount of plaintext encrypted under a given set of keys is approaching the cryptographic limits (as described in [AEAD-LIMITS]).
Actions: Implement a key update as described in Section 4.6.3.
Current Paragraph: There are cryptographic limits on the amount of plaintext which can be safely encrypted under a given set of keys. [AEAD-LIMITS] provides an analysis of these limits under the assumption that the underlying primitive (AES or ChaCha20) has no weaknesses. Implementations SHOULD do a key update as described in Section 4.6.3 prior to reaching these limits.
Next Paragraph: For AES-GCM, up to 2^24.5 full-size records (about 24 million) may be encrypted on a given connection while keeping a safety margin of approximately 2^-57 for Authenticated Encryption (AE) security. For ChaCha20/Poly1305, the record sequence number would wrap before the safety limit is reached.

SR Text: Upon receiving such an alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate end-of-data to the application.
Conditions: Receiving the alert (close_notify) indicating orderly closure of one direction of the connection
Actions: The TLS implementation SHOULD indicate end-of-data to the application
Current Paragraph: Alert messages convey a description of the alert and a legacy field that conveyed the severity level of the message in previous versions of TLS. Alerts are divided into two classes: closure alerts and error alerts. In TLS 1.3, the severity is implicit in the type of alert being sent, and the "level" field can safely be ignored. The "close_notify" alert is used to indicate orderly closure of one direction of the connection. Upon receiving such an alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate end-of-data to the application.
Previous Paragraph: TLS provides an Alert content type to indicate closure information and errors. Like other messages, alert messages are encrypted as specified by the current connection state.
Next Paragraph: Error alerts indicate abortive closure of the connection (see Section 6.2). Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection. Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.

SR Text: Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection.
Conditions: Upon receiving an error alert
Actions: Indicate an error to the application,Do not allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection
Current Paragraph: Error alerts indicate abortive closure of the connection (see Section 6.2). Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection. Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.
Previous Paragraph: Alert messages convey a description of the alert and a legacy field that conveyed the severity level of the message in previous versions of TLS. Alerts are divided into two classes: closure alerts and error alerts. In TLS 1.3, the severity is implicit in the type of alert being sent, and the "level" field can safely be ignored. The "close_notify" alert is used to indicate orderly closure of one direction of the connection. Upon receiving such an alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate end-of-data to the application.
Next Paragraph: All the alerts listed in Section 6.2 MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal and MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message. Unknown Alert types MUST be treated as error alerts.

SR Text: Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.
Conditions: Failed connections
Actions: Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in those failed connections, with the exception that the PSKs associated with session tickets SHOULD be discarded if possible.
Current Paragraph: Error alerts indicate abortive closure of the connection (see Section 6.2). Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection. Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.
Previous Paragraph: Alert messages convey a description of the alert and a legacy field that conveyed the severity level of the message in previous versions of TLS. Alerts are divided into two classes: closure alerts and error alerts. In TLS 1.3, the severity is implicit in the type of alert being sent, and the "level" field can safely be ignored. The "close_notify" alert is used to indicate orderly closure of one direction of the connection. Upon receiving such an alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate end-of-data to the application.
Next Paragraph: All the alerts listed in Section 6.2 MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal and MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message. Unknown Alert types MUST be treated as error alerts.

SR Text: All the alerts listed in Section 6.2 MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal and MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message.
Conditions: Alerts listed in Section 6.2 are subject to the rule,Unknown Alert types are subject to the rule
Actions: Alerts MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal,Alerts MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message
Current Paragraph: All the alerts listed in Section 6.2 MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal and MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message. Unknown Alert types MUST be treated as error alerts.
Previous Paragraph: Error alerts indicate abortive closure of the connection (see Section 6.2). Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection. Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.
Next Paragraph: Note: TLS defines two generic alerts (see Section 6) to use upon failure to parse a message. Peers which receive a message which cannot be parsed according to the syntax (e.g., have a length extending beyond the message boundary or contain an out-of-range length) MUST terminate the connection with a "decode_error" alert. Peers which receive a message which is syntactically correct but semantically invalid (e.g., a DHE share of p -1, or an invalid enum) MUST terminate the connection with an "illegal_parameter" alert.

SR Text: Unknown Alert types MUST be treated as error alerts.
Conditions: When an alert with an unknown alert type is received
Actions: Treat the unknown alert as an error alert
Current Paragraph: All the alerts listed in Section 6.2 MUST be sent with AlertLevel=fatal and MUST be treated as error alerts when received regardless of the AlertLevel in the message. Unknown Alert types MUST be treated as error alerts.
Previous Paragraph: Error alerts indicate abortive closure of the connection (see Section 6.2). Upon receiving an error alert, the TLS implementation SHOULD indicate an error to the application and MUST NOT allow any further data to be sent or received on the connection. Servers and clients MUST forget the secret values and keys established in failed connections, with the exception of the PSKs associated with session tickets, which SHOULD be discarded if possible.

Actions: Terminate the connection with a 'decode_error' alert

Actions: Terminate the connection with an 'illegal_parameter' alert

SR Text: Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored.
Conditions: Any data that is received after a closure alert has been received
Actions: The received data MUST be ignored
Current Paragraph: close_notify: This alert notifies the recipient that the sender will not send any more messages on this connection. Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored.
Previous Paragraph: The client and the server must share knowledge that the connection is ending in order to avoid a truncation attack.
Next Paragraph: user_canceled: This alert notifies the recipient that the sender is canceling the handshake for some reason unrelated to a protocol failure. If a user cancels an operation after the handshake is complete, just closing the connection by sending a "close_notify" is more appropriate. This alert SHOULD be followed by a "close_notify". This alert generally has AlertLevel=warning.

SR Text: This alert SHOULD be followed by a "close_notify".
Conditions: When a user_canceled alert is sent to notify that the sender is canceling the handshake (for reasons unrelated to a protocol failure)
Actions: The alert SHOULD be followed by a close_notify alert to indicate the sender will not send any more messages on the connection
Current Paragraph: user_canceled: This alert notifies the recipient that the sender is canceling the handshake for some reason unrelated to a protocol failure. If a user cancels an operation after the handshake is complete, just closing the connection by sending a "close_notify" is more appropriate. This alert SHOULD be followed by a "close_notify". This alert generally has AlertLevel=warning.
Previous Paragraph: close_notify: This alert notifies the recipient that the sender will not send any more messages on this connection. Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored.
Next Paragraph: Either party MAY initiate a close of its write side of the connection by sending a "close_notify" alert. Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored. If a transport-level close is received prior to a "close_notify", the receiver cannot know that all the data that was sent has been received.

SR Text: Either party MAY initiate a close of its write side of the connection by sending a "close_notify" alert.
Conditions: A party decides to initiate a close of its write side of the connection (i.e., when it opts to begin the closing process)
Actions: The party sends a 'close_notify' alert to initiate the closure of its write side of the connection
Current Paragraph: Either party MAY initiate a close of its write side of the connection by sending a "close_notify" alert. Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored. If a transport-level close is received prior to a "close_notify", the receiver cannot know that all the data that was sent has been received.
Previous Paragraph: user_canceled: This alert notifies the recipient that the sender is canceling the handshake for some reason unrelated to a protocol failure. If a user cancels an operation after the handshake is complete, just closing the connection by sending a "close_notify" is more appropriate. This alert SHOULD be followed by a "close_notify". This alert generally has AlertLevel=warning.
Next Paragraph: Each party MUST send a "close_notify" alert before closing its write side of the connection, unless it has already sent some error alert. This does not have any effect on its read side of the connection. Note that this is a change from versions of TLS prior to TLS 1.3 in which implementations were required to react to a "close_notify" by discarding pending writes and sending an immediate "close_notify" alert of their own. That previous requirement could cause truncation in the read side. Both parties need not wait to receive a "close_notify" alert before closing their read side of the connection, though doing so would introduce the possibility of truncation.

SR Text: Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored.
Conditions: Data received after a closure alert has been received
Actions: The data MUST be ignored

If a transport-level close is received prior to a "close_notify", the receiver cannot know that all the data that was sent has been received.

This alert generally has AlertLevel=warning.

Note that this is a change from versions of TLS prior to TLS 1.3 in which implementations were required to react to a "close_notify" by discarding pending writes and sending an immediate "close_notify" alert of their own. That previous requirement could cause truncation in the read side. Both parties need not wait to receive a "close_notify" alert before closing their read side of the connection, though doing so would introduce the possibility of truncation.

SR Text: Each party MUST send a "close_notify" alert before closing its write side of the connection, unless it has already sent some error alert
Conditions: A party is about to close its write side of the connection and has not already sent an error alert
Actions: The party MUST send a 'close_notify' alert before closing its write side of the connection
Current Paragraph: Each party MUST send a "close_notify" alert before closing its write side of the connection, unless it has already sent some error alert. This does not have any effect on its read side of the connection. Note that this is a change from versions of TLS prior to TLS 1.3 in which implementations were required to react to a "close_notify" by discarding pending writes and sending an immediate "close_notify" alert of their own. That previous requirement could cause truncation in the read side. Both parties need not wait to receive a "close_notify" alert before closing their read side of the connection, though doing so would introduce the possibility of truncation.
Previous Paragraph: Either party MAY initiate a close of its write side of the connection by sending a "close_notify" alert. Any data received after a closure alert has been received MUST be ignored. If a transport-level close is received prior to a "close_notify", the receiver cannot know that all the data that was sent has been received.
Next Paragraph: If the application protocol using TLS provides that any data may be carried over the underlying transport after the TLS connection is closed, the TLS implementation MUST receive a "close_notify" alert before indicating end-of-data to the application layer. No part of this standard should be taken to dictate the manner in which a usage profile for TLS manages its data transport, including when connections are opened or closed.

SR Text: If the application protocol using TLS provides that any data may be carried over the underlying transport after the TLS connection is closed, the TLS implementation MUST receive a "close_notify" alert before indicating end-of-data to the application layer.
Conditions: When the application protocol using TLS allows that any data may be carried over the underlying transport after the TLS connection is closed.
Actions: The TLS implementation MUST receive a 'close_notify' alert before indicating end-of-data to the application layer.

No part of this standard should be taken to dictate the manner in which a usage profile for TLS manages its data transport, including when connections are opened or closed.

Note that this is a change from versions of TLS prior to TLS 1.3 in which implementations were required to react to a "close_notify" by discarding pending writes and sending an immediate "close_notify" alert of their own. That previous requirement could cause truncation in the read side. Both parties need not wait to receive a "close_notify" alert before closing their read side of the connection, though doing so would introduce the possibility of truncation.
Next Paragraph: Note: It is assumed that closing the write side of a connection reliably delivers pending data before destroying the transport.

SR Text: Upon transmission or receipt of a fatal alert message, both parties MUST immediately close the connection.
Conditions: Upon transmission of a fatal alert message,Upon receipt of a fatal alert message
Actions: Both parties MUST immediately close the connection
Current Paragraph: Error handling in TLS is very simple. When an error is detected, the detecting party sends a message to its peer. Upon transmission or receipt of a fatal alert message, both parties MUST immediately close the connection.
Next Paragraph: Whenever an implementation encounters a fatal error condition, it SHOULD send an appropriate fatal alert and MUST close the connection without sending or receiving any additional data. In the rest of this specification, when the phrases "terminate the connection" and "abort the handshake" are used without a specific alert it means that the implementation SHOULD send the alert indicated by the descriptions below. The phrases "terminate the connection with an X alert" and "abort the handshake with an X alert" mean that the implementation MUST send alert X if it sends any alert. All alerts defined below in this section, as well as all unknown alerts, are universally considered fatal as of TLS 1.3 (see Section 6). The implementation SHOULD provide a way to facilitate logging the sending and receiving of alerts.

SR Text: Sending this alert is OPTIONAL; servers MAY instead choose to send a "decrypt_error" alert to merely indicate an invalid PSK identity.
Conditions: When PSK key establishment is desired but no acceptable PSK identity is provided by the client.
Actions: Servers MAY choose to send a 'decrypt_error' alert to merely indicate an invalid PSK identity in lieu of sending the unknown_psk_identity alert.
Current Paragraph: unknown_psk_identity: Sent by servers when PSK key establishment is desired but no acceptable PSK identity is provided by the client. Sending this alert is OPTIONAL; servers MAY instead choose to send a "decrypt_error" alert to merely indicate an invalid PSK identity.
Previous Paragraph: bad_certificate_status_response: Sent by clients when an invalid or unacceptable OCSP response is provided by the server via the "status_request" extension (see [RFC6066]).
Next Paragraph: certificate_required: Sent by servers when a client certificate is desired but none was provided by the client.

SR Text: Once all the values which are to be derived from a given secret have been computed, that secret SHOULD be erased.
Conditions: All values which are to be derived from a given secret have been computed.
Actions: Erase the given secret (it SHOULD be erased).
Current Paragraph: Once all the values which are to be derived from a given secret have been computed, that secret SHOULD be erased.
Previous Paragraph: There are multiple potential Early Secret values, depending on which PSK the server ultimately selects. The client will need to compute one for each potential PSK; if no PSK is selected, it will then need to compute the Early Secret corresponding to the zero PSK.

SR Text: Once client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N+1 and its associated traffic keys have been computed, implementations SHOULD delete client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N and its associated traffic keys.
Conditions: client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N+1 and its associated traffic keys have been computed
Actions: delete client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N and its associated traffic keys
Current Paragraph: Once client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N+1 and its associated traffic keys have been computed, implementations SHOULD delete client_/server_application_traffic_secret_N and its associated traffic keys.
Previous Paragraph: The next-generation application_traffic_secret is computed as:

SR Text: Note that this octet string ("Z" in IEEE 1363 terminology) as output by FE2OSP (the Field Element to Octet String Conversion Primitive) has constant length for any given field; leading zeros found in this octet string MUST NOT be truncated.
Conditions: An octet string produced by FE2OSP with constant length for the given field.
Actions: Leading zeros found in this octet string MUST NOT be truncated.
Current Paragraph: For secp256r1, secp384r1, and secp521r1, ECDH calculations (including parameter and key generation as well as the shared secret calculation) are performed according to [IEEE1363] using the ECKAS-DH1 scheme with the identity map as the key derivation function (KDF), so that the shared secret is the x-coordinate of the ECDH shared secret elliptic curve point represented as an octet string. Note that this octet string ("Z" in IEEE 1363 terminology) as output by FE2OSP (the Field Element to Octet String Conversion Primitive) has constant length for any given field; leading zeros found in this octet string MUST NOT be truncated.
Next Paragraph: (Note that this use of the identity KDF is a technicality. The complete picture is that ECDH is employed with a non-trivial KDF because TLS does not directly use this secret for anything other than for computing other secrets.)

SR Text: For these curves, implementations SHOULD use the approach specified in [RFC7748] to calculate the Diffie-Hellman shared secret
Conditions: When operating on the specified elliptic curves,When the computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret results in the all-zero value,When an alternative implementation of these elliptic curves is used
Actions: Use the approach specified in RFC7748 to calculate the Diffie-Hellman shared secret,Check if the computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret is the all-zero value and abort if so, as described in Section 6 of RFC7748,Perform the additional checks specified in Section 7 of RFC7748 when using an alternative implementation
Current Paragraph: For these curves, implementations SHOULD use the approach specified in [RFC7748] to calculate the Diffie-Hellman shared secret. Implementations MUST check whether the computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret is the all-zero value and abort if so, as described in Section 6 of [RFC7748]. If implementors use an alternative implementation of these elliptic curves, they SHOULD perform the additional checks specified in Section 7 of [RFC7748].
Previous Paragraph: -The ECDH shared secret is the result of applying the ECDH scalar multiplication function to the secret key (into scalar input) and the peer's public key (into u-coordinate point input). The output is used raw, with no processing.

SR Text: Implementations MUST check whether the computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret is the all-zero value and abort if so, as described in Section 6 of [RFC7748].
Conditions: The computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret is the all-zero value.
Actions: Implementations MUST check whether the computed Diffie-Hellman shared secret is the all-zero value and abort the operation if that condition is met, as described in Section 6 of [RFC7748].

SR Text: Implementations MUST use the exporter_master_secret unless explicitly specified by the application.
Conditions: No explicit specification by the application to use a different exporter secret
Actions: Implementations MUST use the exporter_master_secret
Current Paragraph: Where Secret is either the early_exporter_master_secret or the exporter_master_secret. Implementations MUST use the exporter_master_secret unless explicitly specified by the application. The early_exporter_master_secret is defined for use in settings where an exporter is needed for 0-RTT data. A separate interface for the early exporter is RECOMMENDED; this avoids the exporter user accidentally using an early exporter when a regular one is desired or vice versa.
Previous Paragraph: TLS-Exporter(label, context_value, key_length) = HKDF-Expand-Label(Derive-Secret(Secret, label, ""), "exporter", Hash(context_value), key_length)
Next Paragraph: If no context is provided, the context_value is zero length. Consequently, providing no context computes the same value as providing an empty context. This is a change from previous versions of TLS where an empty context produced a different output than an absent context. As of this document's publication, no allocated exporter label is used both with and without a context. Future specifications MUST NOT define a use of exporters that permit both an empty context and no context with the same label. New uses of exporters SHOULD provide a context in all exporter computations, though the value could be empty.

SR Text: Future specifications MUST NOT define a use of exporters that permit both an empty context and no context with the same label.
Conditions: When a specification defines an exporter use permitting both an empty context and no context with the same label
Actions: Future specifications MUST NOT define a use of exporters that permit both an empty context and no context with the same label

SR Text: Servers SHOULD provide that level of replay safety by implementing one of the methods described in this section or by equivalent means.
Conditions: When handling 0-RTT early data that may be replayed, leading to possible duplicate processing across multiple server instances (as described in the context of replay attacks).
Actions: Servers SHOULD provide the specified level of replay safety by implementing one of the methods described in this section or by using equivalent means.
Current Paragraph: The first class of attack can be prevented by sharing state to guarantee that the 0-RTT data is accepted at most once. Servers SHOULD provide that level of replay safety by implementing one of the methods described in this section or by equivalent means. It is understood, however, that due to operational concerns not all deployments will maintain state at that level. Therefore, in normal operation, clients will not know which, if any, of these mechanisms servers actually implement and hence MUST only send early data which they deem safe to be replayed.
Previous Paragraph: -Network attackers who take advantage of client retry behavior to arrange for the server to receive multiple copies of an application message. This threat already exists to some extent because clients that value robustness respond to network errors by attempting to retry requests. However, 0-RTT adds an additional dimension for any server system which does not maintain globally consistent server state. Specifically, if a server system has multiple zones where tickets from zone A will not be accepted in zone B, then an attacker can duplicate a ClientHello and early data intended for A to both A and B. At A, the data will be accepted in 0-RTT, but at B the server will reject 0-RTT data and instead force a full handshake. If the attacker blocks the ServerHello from A, then the client will complete the handshake with B and probably retry the request, leading to duplication on the server system as a whole.
Next Paragraph: In addition to the direct effects of replays, there is a class of attacks where even operations normally considered idempotent could be exploited by a large number of replays (timing attacks, resource limit exhaustion and others, as described in Appendix E.5). Those can be mitigated by ensuring that every 0-RTT payload can be replayed only a limited number of times. The server MUST ensure that any instance of it (be it a machine, a thread, or any other entity within the relevant serving infrastructure) would accept 0-RTT for the same 0-RTT handshake at most once; this limits the number of replays to the number of server instances in the deployment. Such a guarantee can be accomplished by locally recording data from recently received ClientHellos and rejecting repeats, or by any other method that

Conditions: In normal operation, clients do not know which, if any, replay-safety mechanisms the server implements.
Actions: Clients MUST only send early data which they deem safe to be replayed.

Next Paragraph: provides the same or a stronger guarantee. The "at most once per server instance" guarantee is a minimum requirement; servers SHOULD limit 0-RTT replays further when feasible.

Conditions: When the server instance is processing 0-RTT handshake replaysi.e. after ensuring the minimum 'at most once per server instance' replay guaranteethe potential exists for additional replays.
Actions: Servers SHOULD limit further 0-RTT replays beyond the minimum guarantee when feasible.

Next Paragraph: The second class of attack cannot be prevented at the TLS layer and MUST be dealt with by any application. Note that any application whose clients implement any kind of retry behavior already needs to implement some sort of anti-replay defense.

SR Text: The second class of attack cannot be prevented at the TLS layer and MUST be dealt with by any application.
Conditions: The scenario in which a second class of attack occurs that cannot be prevented at the TLS layer
Actions: Any application MUST deal with the second class of attack, including implementing appropriate anti-replay defenses if clients implement any kind of retry behavior
Current Paragraph: The second class of attack cannot be prevented at the TLS layer and MUST be dealt with by any application. Note that any application whose clients implement any kind of retry behavior already needs to implement some sort of anti-replay defense.
Previous Paragraph: provides the same or a stronger guarantee. The "at most once per server instance" guarantee is a minimum requirement; servers SHOULD limit 0-RTT replays further when feasible.

SR Text: Servers MAY also implement data stores with false positives, such as Bloom filters, in which case they MUST respond to apparent replay by rejecting 0-RTT but MUST NOT abort the handshake.
Conditions: The server implements a data store with false positives (e.g., using Bloom filters) and detects an apparent replay of a ClientHello.
Actions: The server MUST reject 0-RTT and MUST NOT abort the handshake.
Current Paragraph: If the expected_arrival_time is in the window, then the server checks to see if it has recorded a matching ClientHello. If one is found, it either aborts the handshake with an "illegal_parameter" alert or accepts the PSK but rejects 0-RTT. If no matching ClientHello is found, then it accepts 0-RTT and then stores the ClientHello for as long as the expected_arrival_time is inside the window. Servers MAY also implement data stores with false positives, such as Bloom filters, in which case they MUST respond to apparent replay by rejecting 0-RTT but MUST NOT abort the handshake.
Previous Paragraph: In order to implement this, when a ClientHello is received, the server first verifies the PSK binder as described in Section 4.2.11. It then computes the expected_arrival_time as described in the next section and rejects 0-RTT if it is outside the recording window, falling back to the 1-RTT handshake.
Next Paragraph: The server MUST derive the storage key only from validated sections of the ClientHello. If the ClientHello contains multiple PSK identities, then an attacker can create multiple ClientHellos with different binder values for the less-preferred identity on the assumption that the server will not verify it (as recommended by Section 4.2.11). I.e., if the client sends PSKs A and B but the server prefers A, then the attacker can change the binder for B without affecting the binder for A. If the binder for B is part of the storage key, then this ClientHello will not appear as a duplicate, which will cause the ClientHello to be accepted, and may cause side effects such as replay cache pollution, although any 0-RTT data will not be decryptable because it will use different keys. If the validated binder or the ClientHello.random is used as the storage key, then this attack is not possible.

SR Text: The server MUST derive the storage key only from validated sections of the ClientHello.
Conditions: When processing a ClientHello message for storage key derivation
Actions: The server MUST derive the storage key only from validated sections of the ClientHello
Current Paragraph: The server MUST derive the storage key only from validated sections of the ClientHello. If the ClientHello contains multiple PSK identities, then an attacker can create multiple ClientHellos with different binder values for the less-preferred identity on the assumption that the server will not verify it (as recommended by Section 4.2.11). I.e., if the client sends PSKs A and B but the server prefers A, then the attacker can change the binder for B without affecting the binder for A. If the binder for B is part of the storage key, then this ClientHello will not appear as a duplicate, which will cause the ClientHello to be accepted, and may cause side effects such as replay cache pollution, although any 0-RTT data will not be decryptable because it will use different keys. If the validated binder or the ClientHello.random is used as the storage key, then this attack is not possible.
Previous Paragraph: If the expected_arrival_time is in the window, then the server checks to see if it has recorded a matching ClientHello. If one is found, it either aborts the handshake with an "illegal_parameter" alert or accepts the PSK but rejects 0-RTT. If no matching ClientHello is found, then it accepts 0-RTT and then stores the ClientHello for as long as the expected_arrival_time is inside the window. Servers MAY also implement data stores with false positives, such as Bloom filters, in which case they MUST respond to apparent replay by rejecting 0-RTT but MUST NOT abort the handshake.
Next Paragraph: Because this mechanism does not require storing all outstanding tickets, it may be easier to implement in distributed systems with high rates of resumption and 0-RTT, at the cost of potentially weaker anti-replay defense because of the difficulty of reliably storing and retrieving the received ClientHello messages. In many such systems, it is impractical to have globally consistent storage of all the received ClientHellos. In this case, the best anti-replay protection is provided by having a single storage zone be authoritative for a given ticket and refusing 0-RTT for that ticket in any other zone. This approach prevents simple replay by the attacker because only one zone will accept 0-RTT data. A weaker design is to implement separate storage for each zone but allow 0-RTT in any zone. This approach limits the number of replays to once per zone. Application message duplication of course remains possible with either design.

SR Text: When implementations are freshly started, they SHOULD reject 0-RTT as long as any portion of their recording window overlaps the startup time.
Conditions: Implementations are freshly started and have any portion of their recording window overlapping the startup time
Actions: Reject 0-RTT
Current Paragraph: When implementations are freshly started, they SHOULD reject 0-RTT as long as any portion of their recording window overlaps the startup time. Otherwise, they run the risk of accepting replays which were originally sent during that period.
Previous Paragraph: Because this mechanism does not require storing all outstanding tickets, it may be easier to implement in distributed systems with high rates of resumption and 0-RTT, at the cost of potentially weaker anti-replay defense because of the difficulty of reliably storing and retrieving the received ClientHello messages. In many such systems, it is impractical to have globally consistent storage of all the received ClientHellos. In this case, the best anti-replay protection is provided by having a single storage zone be authoritative for a given ticket and refusing 0-RTT for that ticket in any other zone. This approach prevents simple replay by the attacker because only one zone will accept 0-RTT data. A weaker design is to implement separate storage for each zone but allow 0-RTT in any zone. This approach limits the number of replays to once per zone. Application message duplication of course remains possible with either design.
Next Paragraph: Note: If the client's clock is running much faster than the server's, then a ClientHello may be received that is outside the window in the future, in which case it might be accepted for 1-RTT, causing a client retry, and then acceptable later for 0-RTT. This is another variant of the second form of attack described in Section 8.

SR Text: This section describes invariants that TLS endpoints and middleboxes MUST follow.
Conditions: Applies to TLS endpoints and middleboxes (including those operating with earlier versions of TLS)
Actions: TLS endpoints and middleboxes MUST follow the invariants described in this section.
Current Paragraph: This section describes invariants that TLS endpoints and middleboxes MUST follow. It also applies to earlier versions of TLS.
Next Paragraph: TLS is designed to be securely and compatibly extensible. Newer clients or servers, when communicating with newer peers, should negotiate the most preferred common parameters. The TLS handshake provides downgrade protection: Middleboxes passing traffic between a newer client and newer server without terminating TLS should be unable to influence the handshake (see Appendix E.1). At the same time, deployments update at different rates, so a newer client or server MAY continue to support older parameters, which would allow it to interoperate with older endpoints.

SR Text: At the same time, deployments update at different rates, so a newer client or server MAY continue to support older parameters, which would allow it to interoperate with older endpoints.
Conditions: Deployments update at different rates, potentially resulting in newer clients or servers needing to interoperate with older endpoints.
Actions: A newer client or server MAY continue to support older parameters to allow interoperation with older endpoints.

In particular, it MUST generate its own ClientHello containing only parameters it understands, and it MUST generate a fresh ServerHello random value, rather than forwarding the endpoint's value.

SR Text: If clients need to send such alerts, they SHOULD first rekey to the handshake keys if possible.
Conditions: When clients need to send alerts (specifically alerts derived from post-ServerHello messages in the clear or with early data keys)
Actions: Clients SHOULD first rekey to the handshake keys, if possible
Current Paragraph: Note that with the transitions as shown above, clients may send alerts that derive from post-ServerHello messages in the clear or with the early data keys. If clients need to send such alerts, they SHOULD first rekey to the handshake keys if possible.
Previous Paragraph: This appendix provides a summary of the legal state transitions for the client and server handshakes. State names (in all capitals, e.g., START) have no formal meaning but are provided for ease of comprehension. Actions which are taken only in certain circumstances are indicated in []. The notation "K_{send,recv} = foo" means "set the send/recv key to the given key".

SR Text: TLS 1.3 implementations MUST NOT send them but might receive them from older TLS implementations.
Conditions: When constructing outgoing TLS messages that might include values previously used in older TLS versions (i.e. values denoted as '_RESERVED')
Actions: TLS 1.3 implementations MUST NOT include or send these reserved values in any transmitted messages
Current Paragraph: This appendix provides the normative protocol types and the definitions for constants. Values listed as "_RESERVED" were used in previous versions of TLS and are listed here for completeness. TLS 1.3 implementations MUST NOT send them but might receive them from older TLS implementations.
Previous Paragraph: K_recv = handshake | | K_recv = early data [Skip decrypt errors] | +------> WAIT_EOED -+ | | Recv | | Recv EndOfEarlyData | | early data | | K_recv = handshake | +------------+ | | | +> WAIT_FLIGHT2 <--------+ | +--------+--------+ No auth | | Client auth | | | v | WAIT_CERT | Recv | | Recv Certificate | empty | v | Certificate | WAIT_CV | | | Recv | v | CertificateVerify +-> WAIT_FINISHED <---+ | Recv Finished | K_recv = application v CONNECTED
Next Paragraph: Values within "obsolete_RESERVED" ranges are used in previous versions of TLS and MUST NOT be offered or negotiated by TLS 1.3 implementations. The obsolete curves have various known/theoretical weaknesses or have had very little usage, in some cases only due to unintentional server configuration issues. They are no longer considered appropriate for general use and should be assumed to be potentially unsafe. The set of curves specified here is sufficient for interoperability with all currently deployed and properly configured TLS implementations.

Actions: TLS 1.3 implementations MUST NOT offer or negotiate these values.

The obsolete curves have various known/theoretical weaknesses or have had very little usage, in some cases only due to unintentional server configuration issues. They are no longer considered appropriate for general use and should be assumed to be potentially unsafe. The set of curves specified here is sufficient for interoperability with all currently deployed and properly configured TLS implementations.

Next Paragraph: A symmetric cipher suite defines the pair of the AEAD algorithm and hash algorithm to be used with HKDF. Cipher suite names follow the naming convention:

SR Text: Applications SHOULD also enforce minimum and maximum key sizes.
Conditions: When processing certificates or certification paths, particularly when keys or signatures are encountered that could be below accepted security thresholds (e.g., keys weaker than 2048-bit RSA or 224-bit ECDSA).
Actions: Applications SHOULD enforce minimum and maximum key sizes to ensure that keys used in certificates or communications meet the required security criteria.
Current Paragraph: Implementations are responsible for verifying the integrity of certificates and should generally support certificate revocation messages. Absent a specific indication from an application profile, certificates should always be verified to ensure proper signing by a trusted certificate authority (CA). The selection and addition of trust anchors should be done very carefully. Users should be able to view information about the certificate and trust anchor. Applications SHOULD also enforce minimum and maximum key sizes. For example, certification paths containing keys or signatures weaker than 2048-bit RSA or 224-bit ECDSA are not appropriate for secure applications.
Previous Paragraph: TLS uses random values (1) in public protocol fields such as the public Random values in the ClientHello and ServerHello and (2) to generate keying material. With a properly functioning CSPRNG, this does not present a security problem, as it is not feasible to determine the CSPRNG state from its output. However, with a broken CSPRNG, it may be possible for an attacker to use the public output to determine the CSPRNG internal state and thereby predict the keying material, as documented in [CHECKOWAY]. Implementations can provide extra security against this form of attack by using separate CSPRNGs to generate public and private values.
Next Paragraph: Implementation experience has shown that certain parts of earlier TLS specifications are not easy to understand and have been a source of interoperability and security problems. Many of these areas have been clarified in this document, but this appendix contains a short list of the most important things that require special attention from implementors.

SR Text: Clients SHOULD NOT reuse a ticket for multiple connections.
Conditions: When a client attempts to use an already issued ticket for a new connection, thereby reusing a ticket across multiple connections
Actions: Clients SHOULD NOT reuse a ticket for multiple connections
Current Paragraph: Clients SHOULD NOT reuse a ticket for multiple connections. Reuse of a ticket allows passive observers to correlate different connections. Servers that issue tickets SHOULD offer at least as many tickets as the number of connections that a client might use; for example, a web browser using HTTP/1.1 [RFC7230] might open six connections to a server. Servers SHOULD issue new tickets with every connection. This ensures that clients are always able to use a new ticket when creating a new connection.
Previous Paragraph: -Do you verify signatures after making them, to protect against RSA-CRT key leaks [FW15]?
Next Paragraph: Previous versions of TLS offered explicitly unauthenticated cipher suites based on anonymous Diffie-Hellman. These modes have been deprecated in TLS 1.3. However, it is still possible to negotiate parameters that do not provide verifiable server authentication by several methods, including:

SR Text: Servers that issue tickets SHOULD offer at least as many tickets as the number of connections that a client might use; for example, a web browser using HTTP/1.1 [RFC7230] might open six connections to a server.
Conditions: When a server issues tickets and the client may open multiple simultaneous connections (e.g., a web browser using HTTP/1.1 might open six connections)
Actions: The server SHOULD offer at least as many tickets as the number of connections that the client might use.

SR Text: Servers SHOULD issue new tickets with every connection
Conditions: When a client establishes a new connection to the server.
Actions: The server SHOULD issue a new ticket for each new connection.
Current Paragraph: Clients SHOULD NOT reuse a ticket for multiple connections. Reuse of a ticket allows passive observers to correlate different connections. Servers that issue tickets SHOULD offer at least as many tickets as the number of connections that a client might use; for example, a web browser using HTTP/1.1 [RFC7230] might open six connections to a server. Servers SHOULD issue new tickets with every connection. This ensures that clients are always able to use a new ticket when creating a new connection.
Previous Paragraph: -Do you verify signatures after making them, to protect against RSA-CRT key leaks [FW15]?
Next Paragraph: Previous versions of TLS offered explicitly unauthenticated cipher suites based on anonymous Diffie-Hellman. These modes have been deprecated in TLS 1.3. However, it is still possible to negotiate parameters that do not provide verifiable server authentication by several methods, including:

SR Text: If no such mechanism is used, then the connection has no protection against active man-in-the-middle attack; applications MUST NOT use TLS in such a way absent explicit configuration or a specific application profile.
Conditions: No external authentication mechanism (such as explicit configuration, a specific application profile, out-of-band server public key validation, trust on first use, or channel bindings) is applied to the TLS connection
Actions: Applications MUST NOT use TLS in such a way
Current Paragraph: Either technique used alone is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks and therefore unsafe for general use. However, it is also possible to bind such connections to an external authentication mechanism via out-of-band validation of the server's public key, trust on first use, or a mechanism such as channel bindings (though the channel bindings described in [RFC5929] are not defined for TLS 1.3). If no such mechanism is used, then the connection has no protection against active man-in-the-middle attack; applications MUST NOT use TLS in such a way absent explicit configuration or a specific application profile.
Previous Paragraph: -Using a public key contained in a certificate but without validation of the certificate chain or any of its contents.
Next Paragraph: The TLS protocol provides a built-in mechanism for version negotiation between endpoints potentially supporting different versions of TLS.

SR Text: The value of TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version MUST be ignored by all implementations.
Conditions: When processing a TLSPlaintext record, regardless of its legacy_record_version value.
Actions: All implementations MUST ignore the value of TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version.
Current Paragraph: Prior versions of TLS used the record layer version number (TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version and TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version) for various purposes. As of TLS 1.3, this field is deprecated. The value of TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version MUST be ignored by all implementations. The value of TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version is included in the additional data for deprotection but MAY otherwise be ignored or MAY be validated to match the fixed constant value. Version negotiation is performed using only the handshake versions (ClientHello.legacy_version and ServerHello.legacy_version, as well as the ClientHello, HelloRetryRequest, and ServerHello "supported_versions" extensions). In order to maximize interoperability with older endpoints, implementations that negotiate the use of TLS 1.0-1.2 SHOULD set the record layer version number to the negotiated version for the ServerHello and all records thereafter.
Previous Paragraph: TLS 1.x and SSL 3.0 use compatible ClientHello messages. Servers can also handle clients trying to use future versions of TLS as long as the ClientHello format remains compatible and there is at least one protocol version supported by both the client and the server.
Next Paragraph: For maximum compatibility with previously non-standard behavior and misconfigured deployments, all implementations SHOULD support validation of certification paths based on the expectations in this document, even when handling prior TLS versions' handshakes (see Section 4.4.2.2).

SR Text: The value of TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version is included in the additional data for deprotection but MAY otherwise be ignored or MAY be validated to match the fixed constant value
Conditions: When processing a TLSCiphertext record for deprotection
Actions: The value of TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version MUST be included in the additional data used for deprotection

Conditions: Negotiation results in the use of TLS 1.0-1.2
Actions: Set the record layer version number to the negotiated version for the ServerHello and all records thereafter

SR Text: For maximum compatibility with previously non-standard behavior and misconfigured deployments, all implementations SHOULD support validation of certification paths based on the expectations in this document, even when handling prior TLS versions' handshakes (see Section 4.4.2.2).
Conditions: Handling prior TLS versions' handshakes, especially in environments exhibiting non-standard behavior and misconfigured deployments
Actions: Implementations SHOULD support validation of certification paths based on the expectations in the document
Current Paragraph: For maximum compatibility with previously non-standard behavior and misconfigured deployments, all implementations SHOULD support validation of certification paths based on the expectations in this document, even when handling prior TLS versions' handshakes (see Section 4.4.2.2).
Previous Paragraph: Prior versions of TLS used the record layer version number (TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version and TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version) for various purposes. As of TLS 1.3, this field is deprecated. The value of TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version MUST be ignored by all implementations. The value of TLSCiphertext.legacy_record_version is included in the additional data for deprotection but MAY otherwise be ignored or MAY be validated to match the fixed constant value. Version negotiation is performed using only the handshake versions (ClientHello.legacy_version and ServerHello.legacy_version, as well as the ClientHello, HelloRetryRequest, and ServerHello "supported_versions" extensions). In order to maximize interoperability with older endpoints, implementations that negotiate the use of TLS 1.0-1.2 SHOULD set the record layer version number to the negotiated version for the ServerHello and all records thereafter.
Next Paragraph: TLS 1.2 and prior supported an "Extended Master Secret" [RFC7627] extension which digested large parts of the handshake transcript into the master secret. Because TLS 1.3 always hashes in the transcript up to the server Finished, implementations which support both TLS 1.3 and earlier versions SHOULD indicate the use of the Extended Master Secret extension in their APIs whenever TLS 1.3 is used.

SR Text: Because TLS 1.3 always hashes in the transcript up to the server Finished, implementations which support both TLS 1.3 and earlier versions SHOULD indicate the use of the Extended Master Secret extension in their APIs whenever TLS 1.3 is used.
Conditions: Implementations that support both TLS 1.3 and earlier versions when TLS 1.3 is used.
Actions: Indicate the use of the Extended Master Secret extension in their APIs.
Current Paragraph: TLS 1.2 and prior supported an "Extended Master Secret" [RFC7627] extension which digested large parts of the handshake transcript into the master secret. Because TLS 1.3 always hashes in the transcript up to the server Finished, implementations which support both TLS 1.3 and earlier versions SHOULD indicate the use of the Extended Master Secret extension in their APIs whenever TLS 1.3 is used.
Previous Paragraph: For maximum compatibility with previously non-standard behavior and misconfigured deployments, all implementations SHOULD support validation of certification paths based on the expectations in this document, even when handling prior TLS versions' handshakes (see Section 4.4.2.2).
Next Paragraph: A TLS 1.3 client who wishes to negotiate with servers that do not support TLS 1.3 will send a normal TLS 1.3 ClientHello containing 0x0303 (TLS 1.2) in ClientHello.legacy_version but with the correct version(s) in the "supported_versions" extension. If the server does not support TLS 1.3, it will respond with a ServerHello containing an older version number. If the client agrees to use this version, the negotiation will proceed as appropriate for the negotiated protocol. A client using a ticket for resumption SHOULD initiate the connection using the version that was previously negotiated.

SR Text: A client using a ticket for resumption SHOULD initiate the connection using the version that was previously negotiated.
Conditions: A client is using a ticket for resumption.
Actions: The client SHOULD initiate the connection using the version that was previously negotiated.
Current Paragraph: A TLS 1.3 client who wishes to negotiate with servers that do not support TLS 1.3 will send a normal TLS 1.3 ClientHello containing 0x0303 (TLS 1.2) in ClientHello.legacy_version but with the correct version(s) in the "supported_versions" extension. If the server does not support TLS 1.3, it will respond with a ServerHello containing an older version number. If the client agrees to use this version, the negotiation will proceed as appropriate for the negotiated protocol. A client using a ticket for resumption SHOULD initiate the connection using the version that was previously negotiated.

Because TLS 1.3 always hashes in the transcript up to the server Finished, implementations which support both TLS 1.3 and earlier versions SHOULD indicate the use of the Extended Master Secret extension in their APIs whenever TLS 1.3 is used.
Next Paragraph: Note that 0-RTT data is not compatible with older servers and SHOULD NOT be sent absent knowledge that the server supports TLS 1.3. See Appendix D.3.

SR Text: Note that 0-RTT data is not compatible with older servers and SHOULD NOT be sent absent knowledge that the server supports TLS 1.3
Conditions: When the client does not have knowledge that the server supports TLS 1.3 (i.e., when communicating with older servers or lacking explicit confirmation of TLS 1.3 support)
Actions: The client SHOULD NOT send 0-RTT data.
Current Paragraph: Note that 0-RTT data is not compatible with older servers and SHOULD NOT be sent absent knowledge that the server supports TLS 1.3. See Appendix D.3.
Previous Paragraph: A TLS 1.3 client who wishes to negotiate with servers that do not support TLS 1.3 will send a normal TLS 1.3 ClientHello containing 0x0303 (TLS 1.2) in ClientHello.legacy_version but with the correct version(s) in the "supported_versions" extension. If the server does not support TLS 1.3, it will respond with a ServerHello containing an older version number. If the client agrees to use this version, the negotiation will proceed as appropriate for the negotiated protocol. A client using a ticket for resumption SHOULD initiate the connection using the version that was previously negotiated.
Next Paragraph: If the version chosen by the server is not supported by the client (or is not acceptable), the client MUST abort the handshake with a "protocol_version" alert.

SR Text: If the version chosen by the server is not supported by the client (or is not acceptable), the client MUST abort the handshake with a "protocol_version" alert.
Conditions: The version chosen by the server is not supported by the client (or is not acceptable)
Actions: The client MUST abort the handshake with a "protocol_version" alert
Current Paragraph: If the version chosen by the server is not supported by the client (or is not acceptable), the client MUST abort the handshake with a "protocol_version" alert.
Previous Paragraph: Note that 0-RTT data is not compatible with older servers and SHOULD NOT be sent absent knowledge that the server supports TLS 1.3. See Appendix D.3.
Next Paragraph: Some legacy server implementations are known to not implement the TLS specification properly and might abort connections upon encountering TLS extensions or versions which they are not aware of. Interoperability with buggy servers is a complex topic beyond the scope of this document. Multiple connection attempts may be required in order to negotiate a backward-compatible connection; however, this practice is vulnerable to downgrade attacks and is NOT RECOMMENDED.

SR Text: If the "supported_versions" extension is present, the server MUST negotiate using that extension as described in Section 4.2.1.
Conditions: The 'supported_versions' extension is present in the ClientHello message.
Actions: The server MUST negotiate using the 'supported_versions' extension as described in Section 4.2.1.
Current Paragraph: A TLS server can also receive a ClientHello indicating a version number smaller than its highest supported version. If the "supported_versions" extension is present, the server MUST negotiate using that extension as described in Section 4.2.1. If the "supported_versions" extension is not present, the server MUST negotiate the minimum of ClientHello.legacy_version and TLS 1.2. For example, if the server supports TLS 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2, and legacy_version is TLS 1.0, the server will proceed with a TLS 1.0 ServerHello. If the "supported_versions" extension is absent and the server only supports versions greater than ClientHello.legacy_version, the server MUST abort the handshake with a "protocol_version" alert.
Previous Paragraph: Some legacy server implementations are known to not implement the TLS specification properly and might abort connections upon encountering TLS extensions or versions which they are not aware of. Interoperability with buggy servers is a complex topic beyond the scope of this document. Multiple connection attempts may be required in order to negotiate a backward-compatible connection; however, this practice is vulnerable to downgrade attacks and is NOT RECOMMENDED.
Next Paragraph: Note that earlier versions of TLS did not clearly specify the record layer version number value in all cases (TLSPlaintext.legacy_record_version). Servers will receive various TLS 1.x versions in this field, but its value MUST always be ignored.

SR Text: If the "supported_versions" extension is not present, the server MUST negotiate the minimum of ClientHello.legacy_version and TLS 1.2.
Conditions: The 'supported_versions' extension is not present in the ClientHello message.
Actions: The server MUST negotiate the minimum of ClientHello.legacy_version and TLS 1.2.

Actions: Abort the handshake with a 'protocol_version' alert
